Artha Advisory TeamFebruary 16, 2026

The Corporate Veil: Limitless Liability? | Corporate Laws Explained

The primary reason entrepreneurs choose to incorporate a company is Limited Liability. This legal shield ensures that if a company fails, the shareholders' personal assets‚Äîlike their house or car‚Äîare generally safe from creditors.

But is this shield impenetrable? Let's explore the cornerstone legal principle of Separate Legal Entity and the exceptional circumstances where this "Corporate Veil" is lifted.

The Principle: Separate Legal Entity ​

The Companies Act, 2063 states in Section 7 that a company is an autonomous body corporate with perpetual succession. This means:

  • The company is a distinct legal person, separate from its shareholders and directors.
  • It can own property, sue, and be sued in its own name.
  • Shareholders change, but the company remains.

The Classic Case: Salomon v Salomon & Co (1897) ​

This principle was cemented in the famous case of Salomon v Salomon & Co. Mr. Salomon converted his shoe business into a company. He was the majority shareholder and also a secured creditor (debenture holder). When the company went bankrupt, other creditors argued that Salomon and the company were the same person, so he shouldn't be paid first.

The House of Lords ruled:

"The company is at law a different person altogether from the subscribers... and though it may be that after incorporation the business is precisely the same as before, and the same persons are managers... the company is not in law the agent of the subscribers."

This established that a company is not just an alias for its owner. It is a separate legal person.

Artha Advisory TeamFebruary 16, 2026

How to Become a Chartered Accountant (CA) in Nepal?

Chartered Accountancy (CA) is one of the most prestigious and challenging professions in Nepal. Governed by The Institute of Chartered Accountants of Nepal (ICAN), established under the Nepal Chartered Accountants Act, 1997, the CA profession offers immense career growth, respect, and financial stability.

Whether you are a student exploring career options or a graduate looking to switch fields, this guide covers everything you need to know about becoming a CA in Nepal.

What is a Chartered Accountant? ​

Chartered Accountants (CAs) are trusted experts in auditing, accounting, financial reporting, taxation, corporate laws, and business advisory. They play a critical role in the economic development of the country, ensuring financial transparency and compliance for businesses, government bodies, and NGOs.

With the rapid growth of Nepal's economy, CAs are in high demand to hold top management positions in public and private sectors.

Artha Advisory TeamJuly 1, 2024

Understanding Startup Loans and Tax Breaks in Nepal

Is your business a "Startup" in the eyes of the government? If yes, you might be sitting on a goldmine of incentives. The Government of Nepal has introduced specific definitions and benefits to foster entrepreneurship.

1. What qualifies as a "Startup"? ​

According to the Startup Enterprise Loan Fund Procedure 2079, your business must meet these criteria:

  • Age: Registered for less than 7 years.
  • Capital: Paid-up capital less than NPR 50 Lakhs.
  • Revenue: Annual turnover less than NPR 50 Lakhs.
  • Full-Time Staff: Not more than 10 employees.
  • Innovation: Must use creative thinking or technology in production/service.

2. The 25 Lakh Subsidized Loan ​

Qualified startups can apply for a project loan up to NPR 25 Lakhs at a subsidized interest rate (currently around 3%).

  • Collateral: The project itself (no land/building collateral required).
  • Process: Applications are called annually by the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Supplies.
  • Selection: Based on proposal evaluation (viability, job creation, innovation).

3. Tax Holidays (Section 11) ​

The Income Tax Act provides massive relief for specific sectors:

IT & Tech Companies ​

  • 50% Income Tax Exemption for 5 years if you export software/services.
  • 1% Tax Rate regarding recent Finance Acts for BPO/KPO (subject to annual changes).

Manufacturing & Special Industries ​

  • 30% to 100% Exemption for industries established in underdeveloped regions.
  • 10 Year Holiday for Hydropower projects affecting commercial operation.

4. How to Apply? ​

  1. Register: Ensure your company is registered at the OCR and has a PAN.
  2. Audit: Keep your tax filings and audit reports up to date. The government will not lend to non-compliant businesses.
  3. Proposal: Write a solid business plan. Need help? Our analysts can draft a bankable project proposal for you.

Tax TeamJune 25, 2024

Expat Taxation in Nepal: The Complete Guide

Foreign nationals working in Nepal often face confusion regarding their tax liabilities. "Do I pay a flat 25%?" or "Am I subject to social security?" Here is the definitive answer.

Residency Status is Key ​

Your tax liability depends on your stay:

  • Resident: Stay in Nepal for 183 days or more in a fiscal year (Ashad to Ashad).
  • Non-Resident: Stay for less than 183 days.

1. The "Non-Resident" Rule (Flat 25%) ​

If you are a non-resident (e.g., consultants on short-term missions), you are taxed at a flat rate of 25% on your Nepal-sourced income.

  • Benefit: No need to file a full tax return if TDS is deducted finally.
  • Drawback: No deductions allowed (insurance, remote area, etc.).

2. The "Resident" Rule (Progressive Slabs) ​

If you stay >183 days, you are taxed like a Nepali citizen.

  • Slab Rates (FY 2081/82 - Married status):
    • First 600k: 1% (Social Security Tax)
    • Next 200k: 10%
    • Next 300k: 20%
    • Next 900k: 30%
    • Above 20L: 36% (if turnover >5M, 39%)

Surprise: For high earners, the progressive rate (36%+) is higher than the non-resident flat rate (25%).

3. Remuneration Tax (The "Expat Concession") ​

However, Section 87 and Schedule 1 of the Tax Act allows a specific concession. If you are a foreign national employed in Nepal, you might opt for specific treatments based on your contract structure.

Critical Note: Often, employers deduct 1% SST, but technically, if you are not a citizen, the 1% SST might not apply in the same way, though practice varies.

4. Double Taxation Avoidance (DTAA) ​

Nepal has DTAA with countries like India, China, UK, USA, etc. Tax paid in Nepal can often be claimed as a credit in your home country. You will need a Tax Clearance Certificate from the IRD to prove this layer.

5. Repatriating Your Salary ​

To send money home, you need:

  1. Work Permit (Department of Labour).
  2. Tax Clearance Certificate.
  3. Bank Recommendation. Without these, your earnings are stuck in NPR.

Artha Audit TeamJune 15, 2024

Fiscal Year End Closing Checklist (Nepal)

As the Nepali fiscal year draws to a close (Ashad end), accounting teams across the country go into overdrive. To ensure a smooth audit and avoid tax penalties later, here is our essential Fiscal Year End Closing Checklist.

1. üßæ Tax Reconciliation ​

  • VAT Reconciliation: Match your Sales Ledger with your Monthly VAT Returns totals. Any difference? Investigate now.
  • TDS Verification: Cross-check your ETDS login. Have all deducted TDS amounts been deposited?
  • Advance Tax: Ensure you have paid at least 100% of your estimated tax liability by Ashad end to avoid Section 119 fees.

2. üì¶ Inventory Valuation ​

  • Physical Count: Mandate a stock count on the last day of Ashad.
  • Valuation Method: Confirm you are using Cost or Net Realizable Value (NRV), whichever is lower (NAS 2).
  • Slow Moving Stock: Identify obsolete items for potential write-off (requires IRD notification).

3. üè¶ Bank & Loan Confirmation ​

  • Reconcile All Accounts: Not just the main operating account.
  • Loan Statements: Obtain interest certificates and loan balance confirmations.
  • NRB Compliance: Check if your working capital loan exceeds 25% of your turnover.

4. üìâ Depreciation & Amortization ​

  • Fixed Asset Register: Update for any additions/disposals during the year.
  • Capitalization: Ensure major repairs that extend asset life are capitalized, not expensed.

5. üí∞ Provisions & Accruals ​

  • Staff Bonus: Provision 10% for staff bonus (if profitable).
  • Gratuity & Leave: update actuarial valuation liabilities.
  • Expenses: Accrue for audit fees, electricity, and rent for Ashad.

6. ü§ù Vendor & Customer Balances ​

  • Confirmation Letters: Send out balance confirmation requests to major debtors and creditors. This is the #1 audit evidence.

FDI DeskJune 10, 2024

Repatriating Profits from Nepal: A Step-by-Step Guide

For foreign investors, the ease of "Exit" is as important as "Entry". Nepal's Foreign Investment and Technology Transfer Act (FITTA) guarantees the right to repatriate, but the bureaucratic process can be daunting.

What Can You Repatriate? ​

  1. Dividends: Proportional to your share of investment.
  2. Sale of Shares: Proceeds from exiting the venture.
  3. Royalties/Fees: Management fees, technology transfer fees, or trademark royalties (must be pre-approved).
  4. Loan Principal & Interest: If you provided a foreign loan (ECB).

The Approval Process (The "Three-Approvals" System) ​

Step 1: Sectoral Approval (DOI / IBN) ​

Before sending money, you must have your initial investment and Share Purchase Agreement (SPA) recorded at the Department of Industry (DOI) or Investment Board Nepal (IBN).

  • Requirement: Evidence that the money came in via banking channels originally ("Niyantran" letter).

Step 2: Tax Clearance (The Big Hurdle) ​

You cannot send a rupee out without a clean chit from the taxman.

  • Full Audit: Your company must undergo a full tax audit for the relevant years.
  • Dividend Tax: Ensure 5% (or treaty rate) Dividend WHT is deducted and paid.

Step 3: Central Bank (NRB) Recommendation ​

The final gatekeeper is Nepal Rastra Bank. You need to apply to the Foreign Exchange Management Department.

  • Documents Needed:
    • Board Minute approving dividend.
    • Audit Report.
    • Tax Clearance Certificate.
    • Evidence of FDI recording.

Common Roadblocks ​

  • Missing "Niyantran" Letter: If you didn't record your initial investment entry at NRB, you are stuck. Retroactive recording is difficult.
  • Working Capital Issues: If your company has negative reserves, you cannot declare dividends even if you have cash.

Artha Advisory TeamMay 20, 2024

Navigating the New Money Laundering Directive 2082

Is your real estate transaction compliant with the latest government directive?

The Government of Nepal has recently issued the Money Laundering Prevention and Combating Terrorism Financing Directive, 2082, introducing stringent measures for high-value transactions, particularly in the real estate sector. This move aims to curb the flow of illicit funds and align Nepal with international Financial Action Task Force (FATF) standards.

üö® Key Threshold: The 10 Lakh Rule ​

The most significant change is the introduction of a lower threshold for mandatory "Source of Funds" declarations.

  • Old Rule: Scrutiny focused primarily on transactions above NPR 1 Crore.
  • New Rule: Any land or property transaction exceeding NPR 10 Lakhs now requires the buyer to disclose the legitimate source of income.

üìù Mandatory Banking Channels ​

Cash is no longer king. The directive mandates that any payment for real estate exceeding the specified limit must be routed through banking channels.

  • Cheques / Drafts / RTGS: Must be used for the transaction value.
  • Cash Payments: Strictly discouraged and may trigger a "Suspicious Transaction Report" (STR) by the Land Revenue Office (Malpot).

üè¢ Impact on Real Estate Companies ​

If you are a developer or a housing company, your compliance burden has increased. You are now classified as a Reporting Entity. This means you must:

  1. KYC: Maintain detailed Know Your Customer records for all buyers.
  2. Reporting: Automatically report transactions exceeding NPR 10 Lakhs to the Financial Information Unit (FIU) of Nepal Rastra Bank.
  3. Risk Assessment: Conduct an internal risk assessment of your clients.

‚ö†Ô∏è Penalties for Non-Compliance ​

Failure to adhere to these new norms can result in:

  • Freezing of the asset.
  • Fines up to 500% of the transaction value.
  • Criminal prosecution for money laundering abetment.

‚úÖ Action Plan for Buyers & Sellers ​

  1. Document Everything: Keep tax clearance certificates and bank statements ready to prove your income source.
  2. Use Formal Channels: Avoid "Undervaluation" (Kaili Chodine) practices. The gap between the Government Valuation and Market Price is being closely monitored.
  3. Consult Experts: Before signing that deed, ensure your paper trail is clean.
